pros: * lots of people you know with business degree from Dal * prestigious - still considered the top university in the area
cons: * constant self promotion/hype from some profs joking about other universities in the area being inferior * when you meet the students from those universities (and their profs) at competitions, etc you will learn how much support they getting from their profs, of their better financing, facilities, connections to employers, which will make you wonder if you made the right choice. * social drinking is being promoted at all levels. Personally was not a problem for me, but I can imagine how isolated somebody else who does not drink would feel.

pros: Very friendly coworkers, casual work environment, two credits free per semester (if you could get your manager to approve)
cons: Management considers themselves above the union staff, little regard for calling union staff professionals and treating them as such, people promoted way beyond their capability to lead, Human Resources only out to protect the brand name - not necessarily the staff within.  I have witnessed and experience first hand harassment by incompetent management. There is little promotability from within.  I have dealt with management who informed me they only hire outside because they want a perfect fit for the hard skill set, instead of taking a tried and true internal candidate and training them for the job.  The union requirement to interview union staff first is a joke.  That being said, because staff fall under the union environment, there is a lot of feeling of entitlement by union staff that they are in their positions for life.

pros: Great colleagues and co-workers.  The kind of work we do, teaching and research, is meaningful and fruitful.
cons: It often feels like those at the very top of the institution (especially the board of govorners) don't really understand how academic institutions work. Quite often a corporate logic which really contradicts the professional identities of people in the institution.  Lots of people poor all their energy and time into their work because its important to them.  When the administration treats these same people like employees who have to be carefully watched and controlled, they risk turning them into that.  People work to rule.  For example, in our department, we have administrative staff who work hard and are committed to helping faculty and students.  They used to do things like stay late or come in on weekends in a moment of crisis.  In exchange, they had more descretion in quiet times.  Now they get in trouble if they shift their hours up a half hour.  this strikes me as counterproductive.

review_title: Reasonable Graduate Teaching Assistant conditions but variable by faculty supervisor
job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Halifax, NS
pros:
- unionized graduate teaching assistants and research assistants 
- decent pay rates 
- some faculty supervisors were very conscientious about not exceeding allotted paid hours for teaching assistants
- opportunities for teaching professional development workshops
- opportunity to engage with passionate undergraduate students
cons:
- teaching assistants vulnerable to being pushed to work additional, unpaid hours by faculty supervisors 
- lack of transparency in awarding contracts

pros: Great benefits; exciting and educational environment; clear rules and regulations; diverse environment.
cons: Support staff are not treated well in many departments. I believe this is a reflection of poor representation by the NSGEU local 77 and the university's HR department than it is with the overall culture of Dalhousie. Troublemakers within the union are moved around the university rather than fired. Abusive professors or higher administrative staff are not reprimanded for their behaviour.

pros: I got to work on a wide variety of projects - I worked on literally whatever needed to be done, from software engineering to physical work in the server racks. I also had a lot of autonomy in terms of work hours and self-directed projects. I was encouraged to learn new technologies and skills for projects assigned to me, rather than just getting things done as soon as possible.
cons: Pay was paltry, even for a part-time student job. The experience and networking was the real payment. It was sometimes hard to know where a particular project fit into the larger scheme of what the team was doing.

job_title: Systems Support Clerk in Halifax, NS
pros: the pay isn't bad, the work conditions are good, good benefits including vacation, sick time, holidays etc.  Work 6.5 hour days.  Great co-workers.
cons: not all perks are available to all workers, but Dal has become a top 100 employer because they offer them.  They MIGHT be available, but it's up to the manager not a University policy and if you have a manager that is a control freak etc, then you'll never have access to the perk - i.e. working from home.

review_title: Grant paid employees in the medical sciences need better support and resources
pros: Opportunity to learn from a wide variety of knowledgeable people and collaborate.
cons: Grant paid research employees in the sciences have little to no support and are constantly reminded that paying salaries are the most expensive part of laboratory budgets.  Never expect a pay increase and in actuality you are most likely going to receive a decrease the longer you are there as you will be shared by more than one researcher with the expectation that you should be able to manage it during normal business hours.

pros: Punches above its weight in the research arena (and on international rankings), especially given the fact that it is only 15,000 undergraduate students.
cons: It is behind many peer institutions in terms of infrastructure and key resources (student services, etc) because of budget challenges.  It receives only half of its funding from government (compared to 75% in Alberta or SK), which means it relies heavily on student tuition for everything.

review_title: Not so good for research associate
pros: I have been working at Dal as research associate for almost 10 years. We can work flexible hours and most investigators are nice and knowledgeable.
cons: No room for career growth and Dal treats research associates unfairly.  We are not considered to be employee of Dal. No dental, no tuition discount, no pension. RRSP match was only added couple years ago when there was a movement to unionize research associates.

review_title: Viewpoint of a Grad Student:  Poor bureaucracy, good freedoms.
job_title: Physics and Atmospheric Science Graduate Student in Halifax, NS
pros:
Location: Halifax is an excellent small city that feels like a big city.
Reputation:  Dalhousie focuses on research instead of students, and the excellent work coming out of this university (and mediocre student experience) reflect that.
Money:  The good reputation of the school means the prof. generally have more money to hire grad students with.
Research opportunities for Undergrads:  For those undergrads that want lab experience, there are ample opportunities in the sciences to get lab positions while still in undergrad.
Co-Curricular Record:  Official stuff you do outside your studies gets officially recorded for the benefit of your resume.
Support Services:  Whether you're an international student or a typical grad student suffering from depression there are free support services that are quite helpful.
Control over your time:  Depending on your supervisor, you can have quite a bit of control over how much time you work/vacation.
cons:
Payroll:  How they manage to make a mistake in my pay every September, I don't know.  Their organization must be a complex maze for as many errors to surface as I've seen in simple things like renewing your pay for a new year.
General paperwork for the program:  It takes a while to figure out what has to be signed and who has to sign it.  See complex maze comment above.
Grad student classes:  The professors do not get any real credit for teaching graduate student level classes, so they don't tend to put a lot of effort in and the result is poorly taught classes.

job_title: Research Assistant/Teaching Assistant/Seasonal Lecturer in Halifax, NS
pros: It's a nice campus, every department would be a different work environment so you could find somewhere that you fit in. Vacation pay included in pay.
cons: Sometimes the pay stub is confusing. I've noticed that sometimes the university will double up my two different jobs (paid for by different funds, one is a grant for research and the other is department funds) into one pay and I end up paying more in taxes and fees, which seems unfair to me.

job_title: IT Help Desk in Halifax, NS
pros: I have worked in various departments for Dalhousie University, and it was a very good experience in each one of them. Lots of support from supervisors when required and extremely friendly co-workers. This place has a lot of benefits, like free education at the University if you work there.
cons: Almost all the supervisors I had were too nice to ever point out anything that was being done wrong. This allowed some people to slack off cause they did not dear repercussions.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Halifax, NS
pros: Working with the students is often a lot of fun. The facilities are well set for the task. Responsibilities are reasonable and clear.
cons: Being a TA has the same cons anywhere, I expect. Grading assignments and exams is 95% boring, but the amount of the job that encompasses is a small fraction.

pros: As a larger organization Dalhousie has a lot of support. Communicators across the campuses and faculties meet regularly and professional training sessions take place.
cons: Because of the size and nature of the employer, it is easy to become narrow focused on just your area. The other downside is there can be a struggle to get your story in the news as there are so many stories being created across all the campuses.

pros:
Happy and friendly atmosphere.
Flexible to balance between your job and your other activities.
cons:
Indiscriminate, and racism.
In favor of Canadian students than International students.
Force you to finish early, even if you are in your best track.

review_title: I had a great experiene at Dalhousie for my master's degree.
pros:
Great University in a great city
Really supportive faculty and staff to help you through
cons:
High tuition rates- Some of the highest in the country, but this is also program dependent
Non-guaranteed funding- Dalhousie doesn't have as much funding for students as other larger institutions, and doesn't have minimum guaranteed levels. My department tried to ensure students were fully funded (20,000/year for master's students), but this is outside their ability.

pros: It is a very relaxing place to live and to work in. Climate is lovely. People are all nice and kind.
cons: Maybe sometimes, you know, the city is a little bit too relaxing and slow-moving. For young guys, maybe it is not a perfect idea.

pros: Sense of common struggle with fellow employees....?
cons: Constantly changing software systems, policies and procedures some of which were overhauled for the sake of manager-turnover (appearance of making changes) not because they made operational sense. University tended to hire externally for senior positions even though well-qualified staff already existed within the ranks. This lead to dissatisfaction and issues with morale. Internal strife and politics in terms of clinicians having to be appreciated for their clinical schedules lead to teaching schedules being a non-priotrity at best, a burden at worst.

pros: Situated in a very friendly small city; there are plenty of Teaching Assistant jobs available if you get familiar with the professors
cons: There is a 130-hour limit per semester to work as a teaching assistant; the payment for undergraduate students is significantly lower than graduate students

review_title: Great place to work while attending school
pros: The salaries are great for students. I recommend working at the Access and Advising Centre. Students will earn $12/hour for proctoring. Also, your education comes first, thus they are very accommodation around exam and class schedules.
cons: Upper management is not always approachable and sometimes difficult to speak to. I had a couple issues with payroll but they were sorted out quickly.

pros: Great place to study, great company, profs that will push you
cons: Masters degrees can take in excess of two years - this is a long time to be in university. There will be a lot of distractions from your work.

pros: People, goals (make a difference for students), researchers who really want to find causes of cancer etc., solve problems, help find cures.
cons: Time flies.  Lack of funding (research).

review_title: I loved to work with Dalhousie University.
pros: They hiring procedure is tranparant. They usually don't fire people. They offer competitive salary.
cons: It is not in a big city. Do not have much industry around. In order to grow you have to move to a bigger city.

review_title: Great place to work at as a student
pros: Most of the employers are nice and very flexible with scheduling. They are very considerate and put your studies ahead of work. The customer base is always students, which is nice.
cons: Most of the jobs are minimum wage even though they require a lot of work than just standing behind a cash machine.

job_title: Communications Officer, Administrative Assistant in Halifax, NS
pros:
Since 2013, I've worked with fantastic coworkers who've become friends, knowledgeable management; and, made many connections among different faculties and departments. 

Working at Dal is a great opportunity to advance your experience in your field, build professional relationships, with an opportunity to move up in your role - even if it requires changing departments!
cons: Some departments are understaffed, resulting in an inflated workload.

pros: Active president, great employees at the entry level
cons: Horrible management. You will be recruited on false promises of advancement opportunities, secondments, a work/life balance and a positive work environment. Your application to offer process is going to take 2-3 months at best. Contracts get terminated early all the time without cause (yes, it's legal they built it into several job groups) if upper management doesn't like you or needs a scapegoat and they "disappear" folk all the time. There were at least 4 people during my 2 years that just suddenly weren't there without notice or explanation. The institution is the most siloed of any institution I have worked at which includes 3 other U15 institutions and communication, even within departments is slow, lacking forethought or deliberation or non-existent and worse inter departmentally. Internal talent with experience, proven track records and good rapport with direct reports are often passed over so that they don't outshine the folk above them or actively pushed out. If you have a middle management position beware the toxic environment above you as many of the executive suite's expectations border on exploitative of their front line staff in student affairs. Again, you'll be recruited with promises of work life balance but once on the job, you'll be expected to be accessible via email at all times, expected to work without credit on weekend and evenings without time in lieu and there is no leeway should you suffer any setbacks in your personal life. Of the U15 institutions, Dalhousie has an average pay BUT the worst benefits with minimal eye care & dental coverage, no personal spending account and no employee fitness initiatives. This is also the least valued I have felt as a female at a U15. Male colleagues were not held to the same standard and were assigned plum assignments with opportunity for growth while the females, myself included, were often assigned the volunteer work that meant working outside of office hours, on your own time with less prestige and little to no credit for the work being put in. Your analytical and thinking skills will be all but ignored and you'll be expected to do much of the emotional labour while maybe getting a compliment on your soft skills.

pros: Enables innovation by providing a collegial and collaborative environment for faculty, students and administrative workers. The University is in a community that enables excellence.
cons: The workload is not evenly distributed; partly because the menu of attractive activities is so large that some people find it hard to restrain their enthusiasm.

job_title: Director of Planned Giving in Halifax, NS
pros: From my perspective, it is a terrific organization with great people and a supportive work environment.  New ideas are encouraged and supported.
cons: Typical for a non-private sector organization, decision making takes a little bit longer.   If you have patients and a firm belief in your efforts this is not a challenge :)

pros: Dalhousie is a community based employer. They work hard at involving everyone in social events. Benefits for my future are great. I am more than just a number!
cons: Being paid once a month is my only complaint! But I'm used to it now, so if it changed I probably wouldn't like it!

pros: I had the chance to work under wonderful advisers. They were all knowledgeable, and knew how to direct us without specifically giving us the path we needed, and made sure to give us plenty of conference opportunities.
cons: Finding funding/pay can be haphazard. Most of our departments funding was external, which influenced the direction of the studies.

job_title: Dal Student Life Marketing Team in Halifax, NS
pros: Really great way to connect with the student community. Allows you to work independently with extremely flexible hours for students.
cons: Can be low paying but, as it's an hourly paid job, you get what you give. You're encouraged to run with your campaign ideas and can easily earn more hours of pay.

review_title: University is a good place for a faculty, not a good place for a staff without work union.

cons: If your salary is supported by research funding, you will need to work hard and cross your finger and wish good luck will always come to you.

cons: Sometimes the vibe in the Henry Hicks building could be a little stuffy.
